Identification.LongTitle: Regulations Respecting Fishing in the Provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island and in Adjacent Tidal Waters

Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, pursuant to sections 8, 43* and 46 of the Fisheries Act, is pleased hereby to revoke the Nova Scotia Fishery Regulations, C.R.C., c. 848, the New Brunswick Fishery Regulations, C.R.C., c. 844, and the Prince Edward Island Fishery Regulations, C.R.C., c. 850, and to make the annexed Regulations respecting fishing in the provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island and in adjacent tidal waters, in substitution therefor, effective February 24, 1993.

Section.Text: These Regulations may be cited as the Maritime Provinces Fishery Regulations.

Subsection.Text: In these Regulations,

Definition.Text: Act means the Fisheries Act; (Loi)

angling means fishing with a line to which one or more hooks are attached and that is held in the hand or attached to a rod that is held in the hand or closely attended; (pêche à la ligneouà la ligne)

artificial fly means a single hook, a double hook or two single hooks that are dressed with materials likely to attract fish and to which no weight, spinning device or natural bait is attached; (mouche artificielle)
bag net means a net

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that is attached to stakes or buoys,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the bag of which floats with the tide or current, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is used to catch fish without enmeshing them; (filet à poche)

Definition.Text: brook trout includes any hybrid of brook trout, but does not include splake; (omble de fontaine)
clams includes bar clams, bay quahaugs, razor clams and soft-shell clams; (clams)
day means a calendar day; (jour ou journée)
Department means the Department of Fisheries and Oceans; (ministère)
dip net means a bag-like net that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fixed to a frame to which a handle is attached, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manipulated by hand to catch fish without enmeshing them; (épuisette)

Definition.Text: drag rake means a device used in fishing for shellfish that is towed along the bed of the water by a vessel, but does not include a hydraulic device or a mechanical device; (râteau traînant)
drift net means a gill net that drifts in the water, whether or not it is attached to a vessel, and includes a gill net that is not anchored at both ends; (filet dérivant)
foreign fishing vessel has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Coastal Fisheries Protection Act; (bateau de pêche étranger)
gill net means a net by which fish are caught by being enmeshed and that does not enclose an area of water; (filet maillant)
hook, in relation to angling, means a single, double or treble hook, with or without barbs, on one shank or shaft; (hameçon)
hydraulic device means a device used in fishing for shellfish whereby the shellfish are lifted from the bed of the water by the use of water under pressure; (dispositif hydraulique)
inland waters means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all waters of a river, stream or brook set out in column I of an item of Schedule II that are upstream of the boundary or reference point, as the case may be, set out in column II of that item, including any waters tributary thereto that are upstream of that boundary or reference point, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any case not referred to in paragraph (a), all waters that are upstream of the low-water mark at the time of low water as set out in the Canadian Tide and Current Tables published by the Department; (eaux intérieures)

Definition.Text: jigging means fishing by manipulating one or more hooks so as to pierce a fish in any part of its body instead of luring the fish to take the hook or hooks into its mouth; (pêche à la turlutte)
landlocked salmon means non-anadromous salmon; (ouananiche)

leased oyster area means an area for which a special licence or lease has been granted to a person under section 58 or 59 of the Act for the purpose of planting or forming oyster beds or for the cultivation and production of oysters; (secteur ostréicole amodié)
length means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to an eel, the distance measured in a straight line from the tip of the nose to the tip of the caudal fin,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a salmon or a landlocked salmon, the distance measured in a straight line from the tip of the nose to the fork of the tail,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a shellfish, the distance measured in a straight line through the longest part of the shell, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to any other fish referred to in these Regulations, the distance measured in a straight line from the tip of the nose to the tip of the tail; (longueur)

Definition.Text: longline means a line to which two or more hooks are attached at intervals and that is anchored to the bed of the water; (palangre)
mechanical device means any device or equipment used in fishing for shellfish that is not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: hand-held,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a drag rake, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a hydraulic device; (dispositif mécanique)

Definition.Text: mesh size has the same meaning as in subsection 2(1) of the Atlantic Fishery Regulations, 1985; (maillage)
open season means a period of time during which no close time applies; (période d’ouverture)
province means, except in the definition salmon tag, the province of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick or Prince Edward Island; (province)
public oyster-fishing area means any area that is not a leased oyster area; (gisement public de pêche des huîtres)
recreational fishing means fishing solely for pleasure or fishing to catch fish solely for personal use; (pêche récréative)
registration card means a fisher’s registration card or a vessel registration card issued under section 5 or under the Atlantic Fishery Regulations, 1985; (carte d’enregistrement)
salmon means anadromous salmon; (saumon)
salmon tag means a tag that is designed to be affixed to a salmon to identify the source and year of capture of the salmon and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is issued with a licence, written permission or other document under the authority of which the salmon was caught that is issued under

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Act or the regulations made thereunder,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the National Parks Act or the regulations made thereunder,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an Act of the legislature of a province of Canada or the regulations made thereunder, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the laws of any country other than Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is legible, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has not been tampered with; (étiquette à saumon)

Definition.Text: set line means a line that is not attached to a rod or held in the hand and to which only one hook with a single point or barb is attached; (ligne fixe)
shellfish means clams, mussels and oysters; (mollusques et crustacés)
splake means a trout that is a cross between a male brook trout and a female lake trout; (truite moulac)
sport fish means smallmouth bass, landlocked salmon, salmon and trout; (poisson de sport)
square net means a net made of wire or twine and attached to a pole that is manipulated on a pivot so as to lower and raise the net in the water to catch fish without enmeshing them; (carrelet)
tidal waters means, in relation to a county or province, all waters, other than inland waters, that are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within that county or province, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: adjacent to that county or province and closer to that county or province than to any other county or province; (eaux à marée)

Definition.Text: trap net means a net that is set so as to enclose an area of water into which fish are guided through an opening or openings by one or more leaders, including what is commonly referred to as a box net but not including an eel trap; (trappe en filet)
trout means Arctic char, brook trout, brown trout, lake trout and rainbow trout; (truite)
weir has the same meaning as in subsection 2(1) of the Atlantic Fishery Regulations, 1985; (bordigue)
whitefish means lake whitefish and round whitefish. (corégone)

Subsection.Text: A reference in these Regulations to a species or group of species of fish by its common name as set out in column I of an item of Schedule I shall be construed as a reference to the species or group of species whose scientific name is set out in column II that item.
A reference in these Regulations to the weight of fish shall be construed as a reference to the weight of the fish in a completely unprocessed state.

A reference in these Regulations to a grid reference is a grid reference based on the Universal Transverse Mercator Grid system expressed in the North American Datum 1927 (NAD 27) used in the National Topographic Series Maps, Scale 1:50,000, published by the Department of Natural Resources.

Unless otherwise provided or a contrary intention appears, a reference in these Regulations to a river, stream or brook by its proper name shall be construed to include all waters forming part of that river, stream or brook and all waters tributary thereto.
The provisions of these Regulations respecting shellfish that apply to specified waters apply also to the foreshore of those specified waters.
In these Regulations, all geographical coordinates (latitude and longitude) are expressed in the North American Datum 1927 (NAD 27) geodetic reference system.
In these Regulations, the lines connecting points or coordinates are rhumb lines, unless stated otherwise.
These Regulations apply in Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island and in Canadian fisheries waters adjacent to those provinces.
These Regulations do not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fishing for marine mammals;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fishing carried out under the authority of a licence issued under the Atlantic Fishery Regulations, 1985;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: cultivated fish found in or taken from

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an aquaculture area or site operated under a lease or licence issued by the Minister or under the Fisheries and Coastal Resources Act of Nova Scotia or the Aquaculture Act of New Brunswick, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a privately owned fish pond that does not contain any wild fish and to which wild fish have no access;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: national parks where the National Parks Fishing Regulations apply; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign fishing vessel or a person fishing from a foreign fishing vessel, except where the vessel or person is engaged in recreational fishing.

Subsection.Text: Except for this section and sections 2, 4, 6, 18, 19, 22, 25 to 29, 34, 35, 39, 56, 58, and 68, these Regulations do not apply with respect to fishing and related activities carried out under the authority of a licence issued under the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations.
Subject to subsections (2) to (5), no person shall fish for or catch and retain any fish unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: authorized to do so under the authority of a licence issued under these Regulations, the Fishery (General) Regulations or the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: accompanying a person referred to in subparagraph (i) and is fishing for

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: gaspereau with gill nets, trap nets, square nets or weirs,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: shad with gill nets, square nets or trap nets,

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: smelt with bag nets, box nets or gill nets,

Clause.Label: (G)
Clause.Text: tomcod with bag nets, box nets or gill nets;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person holds a fisher’s registration card or a provincial or territorial fisher’s certificate, as defined in section 2 of the Fishery (General) Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where a vessel is used in fishing, a vessel registration card has been issued in respect of that vessel.

Subsection.Text: A person may retain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shad incidentally caught with gaspereau fishing gear operated under the authority of a licence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: tomcod incidentally caught with smelt fishing gear operated under the authority of a licence.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: recreational fishing by angling or with set lines;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: recreational fishing for clams or mussels by hand or with hand-held tools;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: recreational fishing for eels, smelt or tomcod with spears in tidal waters;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: recreational fishing for smelt with dip nets;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: recreational fishing for gaspereau with dip nets in waters other than

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the inland and tidal waters of Prince Edward Island, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the inland waters of the Miramichi River and the Saint John River;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: fishing for oysters in a leased oyster area; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: fishing for minnows with minnow traps or dip nets.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs (1)(b) and (c) do not apply in respect of fishing under the authority of a recreational fishing licence or a licence issued under the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations.
Paragraph (1)(c) does not apply in respect of fishing for oysters in a public oyster-fishing area in the inland or tidal waters of Prince Edward Island or Nova Scotia.

Section.Text: The Minister, upon application for a licence or registration card set out in column I of an item of the table to this section and payment of the fee set out in column II of that item, may issue that licence or registration card.

row.entry: Licence to take oysters during a close time from a leased oyster area

Section.Text: No person shall catch and retain or possess Atlantic whitefish.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall fish in inland waters except by angling.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who is fishing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for gaspereau, smelt or shellfish;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for minnows with minnow traps or dip nets;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: with set lines under Parts XVIII and XIX; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: under the authority of a licence that authorizes fishing in inland waters by means other than angling.

Section.Text: No person shall fish in inland waters with the aid of an artificial light or light from a fire.
No person shall fish or assist in fishing by jigging in inland waters or assist in landing fish that have been caught by jigging in inland waters.
No person shall fish by jigging in the waters set out in column I of the table to this section during the close time set out in column II.

Notwithstanding any open season set out in these Regulations for angling in any inland waters, no person shall angle for any species of fish in those inland waters unless an open season for at least one species of sport fish is in effect in those waters.
No person shall angle in inland waters

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with more than one fishing line; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with a fishing line to which more than three hooks are attached.

Section.Text: No person shall angle in tidal waters for sport fish

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with more than one fishing line; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with a fishing line to which more than three hooks are attached.

Section.Text: No person shall angle in tidal waters for any species of fish other than sport fish

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with more than five fishing lines; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with a fishing line to which more than six hooks are attached.

Section.Text: For greater certainty, the prohibitions set out in sections 11.1 and 11.2 do not apply to fishing for commercial purposes.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall angle for sport fish during the period beginning two hours after sunset and ending two hours before sunrise.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: angling for smallmouth bass in Micmac Lake or Banook Lake in Halifax County, Nova Scotia;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: angling for brown trout in the Cornwallis River, Kings County, Nova Scotia or in the Mersey River, Queens County, Nova Scotia, downstream from Lake Rossignol to the dam at Cowie Falls; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: angling during the period beginning on January 1 and ending on March 31 in the waters set out in section 116 or Schedule IX.

Subsection.Text: Nothwithstanding subsection (1), no person shall angle in the inland waters of Nova Scotia set out in Schedule IV during the period beginning at 22:00 h on any day and ending at 06:00 h on the following day.

Section.Text: Every person who catches a sport fish by hooking it in a part of its body other than its mouth shall forthwith return the fish to the water from which it was caught and, where the fish is alive, release the fish in a manner that causes the least harm to it.
No person shall use a gaff or spear to land a sport fish that has been caught by angling.
No person shall angle or assist in angling from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any bridge in Nova Scotia that spans any waters set out in column I of Schedule IV; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any bridge in New Brunswick that spans the inland waters of or forms the boundary for the inland waters of any river, stream or brook set out in column I of Schedule II.

Subsection.Text: No person shall angle for any species of fish in the waters set out in column I of Schedule IV by a method set out in column II during the close time set out in column III.
The close time established by subsection (1) is considered to be fixed separately and independently for each species of fish found in those waters.
No person shall possess at any time more salmon taken by angling in accordance with these Regulations than the applicable yearly fishing quota for salmon prescribed by these Regulations.

No person shall possess at any time more fish of a species taken by recreational fishing in accordance with these Regulations, except for salmon, than the applicable daily fishing quota for that species prescribed by these Regulations.

Section.Text: No person shall use as bait, or possess for use as bait, in a province any

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: live or dead

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: bass, bullhead, sunfish, white perch, yellow perch or other spiny fin-rayed fish,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: goldfish or other carp, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: chain pickerel; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: live fish that was not taken in that province.

Heading.TitleText: Bait Provisions Specific to New Brunswick

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall use as bait or possess for use as bait in the inland waters of New Brunswick any live fish.

A person may use live fish for bait, or possess live fish for use as bait, in a body of water set out in section 116 if the fish was taken from that body of water and it is not a species of fish set out in paragraph 18(a).

Section.Text: No person shall fish for any species of fish in the waters set out in column I of an item of Schedule III by a method set out in column II of that item during the close time set out in column III of that item.
Every person who fishes with a gill net shall set it in a straight line.
No person in a province shall, without lawful excuse, possess any fishing net other than a dip net.

Subsection.Text: No person shall possess in inland waters or within 15 m of inland waters a jigging device or spear.
No person shall possess in inland waters or within 15 m of inland waters a snare or bow and arrow unless the person is lawfully hunting or trapping under the laws of a province.

Section.Text: Every person who is fishing for gaspereau or shad with a gill net, trap net or weir shall, during the applicable weekly close time for those fish set out in Schedules V and VIII, respectively,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: remove the gill net from the water; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: render the trap net or weir incapable of catching fish.

Section.Text: No person shall fish with a weir constructed in tidal waters that goes dry at low tide unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the weir contains escape gates for the release of fish; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person opens the escape gates before each low tide and releases any incidental catch of fish.

Section.Text: Except as otherwise provided as a condition of a licence, no person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fish for gaspereau in the Gaspereau River, Kings County, Nova Scotia, with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a dip net within 90 m of a square net,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a square net within 60 m of any other square net, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a square net within 60 m of a dam;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fish for smelt or tomcod in waters other than the Miramichi River or Miramichi Bay with a bag net, trap net or gill net within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 45 m of any other bag net, trap net or gill net, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 90 m upstream or downstream of any other bag net, trap net or gill net;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fish for smelt or tomcod in the Miramichi River or Miramichi Bay with a bag net, trap net or gill net within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 90 m of any other bag net, trap net or gill net, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 180 m upstream or downstream of any other bag net, trap net or gill net;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: fish for smelt or tomcod with a bag net, trap net or gill net within 90 m of a bridge; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in any case not provided for in paragraphs (a) to (d), fish with or set any fishing gear, other than angling gear, a dip net, a minnow trap or a spear, within 200 m of any fishing gear previously set.

Section.Text: No person shall leave fishing gear unattended in the water for more than 72 consecutive hours.

Subsection.Text: No person shall, in the provinces of Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia, place a shack or temporary shelter on the ice over any waters, unless the name and address of the owner is painted on or otherwise affixed to the shack or temporary shelter.
The letters and numerals forming the name and address of the owner of a shack or temporary shelter referred to in subsection (1) shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: legible;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not less than 50 mm in height; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a colour that contrasts with their background.

Subsection.Text: No person shall place a shack or temporary shelter on the ice before January 1 in any waters set out in section 116 or Schedule IX.

Every shack or temporary shelter placed on the ice shall be removed by the owner by midnight on April 2, in any year, or, depending on ice conditions, by the earlier or later date as may be specified by a fishery officer.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding any close time or size limit set out in these Regulations, a person may, under the authority of a shellfish replanting licence, fish for shellfish for the purpose of relocating them to improve their growth, condition or accessibility.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: family member has the meaning assigned by paragraph (a) of the definition related persons in subsection 251(2) of the Income Tax Act. (membre de la famille)
inshore family fishing corporation means a corporation that operates an inshore fishing enterprise and that meets the following conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 100% of its voting shares are held by a licence holder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the sole director is the licence holder or, if the licence holder is a corporation, all of the shares of which belong to one individual, that individual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 100% of its non-voting shares, if any, are held by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a member of the licence holder’s family or, if the licence holder is a corporation, all of the shares of which belong to one individual, a member of that individual’s family, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an inshore fishing corporation or an inshore fishing family trust. (société familiale de pêche côtière)

Definition.Text: inshore fishing corporation means a corporation that meets the following conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 100% of its voting shares are held by a licence holder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the sole director is the licence holder or, if the licence holder is a corporation, all of the shares of which belong to one individual, that individual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 100% of its non-voting shares, if any, are held by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a member of the licence holder’s family or, if the licence holder is a corporation, all of the shares of which belong to one individual, a member of that individual’s family, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an inshore fishing corporation or an inshore fishing family trust. (société de pêche côtière)

Definition.Text: inshore fishing family trust means a trust

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that has as its sole trustee a licence holder or, if the licence holder is a corporation all of the shares of which belong to one individual, that individual; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for which each beneficiary must be either a member of the licence holder’s family or, if the licence holder is a corporation all of the shares of which belong to one individual, a member of that individual’s family or an inshore fishing company. (fiducie familiale de pêche côtière)

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of the definition family member, common-law partnership is to be read as a person who is cohabiting with a licence holder in a relationship of a conjugal nature and has done so for a period of at least one year.

Section.Text: This Part applies to the following licences:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an inshore fishing licence that is held by a licence holder that is identified as an independent core licence holder with the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a coastal fishing licence, other than a commercial fishing licence to fish for elver;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an inshore fishing licence with “designated operator status” or “exploitant désigné” or an equivalent expression appearing on it and that is held by a licence holder referred to in paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an inshore fishing licence that is held by a licence holder that is identified as a head of a non-core enterprise with the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an inshore fishing licence with “designated operator status” or “exploitant désigné” or an equivalent expression appearing on it and that is held by a licence holder referred to in paragraph (d);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an inshore fishing licence held by an organization that has been issued an allocation of fish to catch for the benefit of its membership; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: an inshore fishing licence held by a corporation that held such a licence before January 19, 1989, unless

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: “designated operator status” or “exploitant désigné” or an equivalent expression appears on the licence, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the corporation held an inshore fishing licence before January 1, 1979.

Subsection.Text: A licence referred to in paragraphs 29.1(a) to (f) may only be issued to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an individual or their estate or succession;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a corporation, all of the shares of which belong to one individual; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an organization referred to in paragraph 29.1(f).

Subsection.Text: In the case of a licence referred to in paragraph 29.1(a), (b), (d) or (g), the activities authorized under the licence must be carried out personally by the licence holder, the operator named in the licence or a person authorized in accordance with subsection 23(2) of the Fishery (General) Regulations.

A licence referred to in paragraph 29.1(a) or (c) shall not be issued if, at the time of application, the applicant has transferred the use or control of the rights or privileges conferred under the licence for which the applicant is the licence holder or was the licence holder in the 12 months prior to the application or conferred under a licence that may be issued to the applicant.

A licence holder that has been denied the issuance of a licence under subsection (3) or has had a licence cancelled under paragraph 9(1)(b) of the Act and did not resolve the matter that gave rise to the denial, suspension or cancellation within 12 months of the day on which the licence was denied, suspended or cancelled is never eligible to hold the same type of licence again.
Subsection (3) does not apply in the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licence is offered as security in a financial agreement under provincial legislation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case referred to in paragraph (a), a creditor that is a recognized financial institution uses or controls the rights or privileges under the licence in order to exercise its rights with respect to a security;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case referred to in paragraph (a), a creditor that is not a recognized financial institution, uses the privilege under the licence to recommend to the Minister the next licence holder or the reallocation of fishing quota, in order to exercise its rights with respect to a security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a trustee or receiver appointed under the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act uses or controls rights or privileges conferred by the licence;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: all or part of the rights of the proceeds from the sale of the catch are transferred to any person on the vessel who is participating in making the catch;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an applicant that is a licence holder, the rights and privileges under that licence or the rights and privileges to be granted if the application is accepted have been transferred to an inshore family fishing corporation of which the applicant holds 100% of the voting shares;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an applicant that is not a licence holder, the rights and privileges that are granted under the licence if the application is accepted have been transferred to a corporation that would be an inshore family fishing corporation of which the applicant holds 100% of the voting shares if the licence was issued;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: with the authorization of the Minister, the licence holder transfers the rights or privileges under the licence in order to give effect to the following arrangements made with other holders of the licences referred to in any of paragraphs 29.1(a) to (g):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an arrangement for the reallocation of a fishing quota, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an arrangement for the reallocation of authorized fishing gear;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: an organization referred to in paragraph 29.1(f) has required the licence holder to provide part of the proceeds from the sale of the catch back to the organization in exchange for additional fish allocation;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a liquidator of the succession, an executor or an administrator of the estate appointed upon the death of the licence holder uses or controls the rights or privileges under the licence;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a person is authorized to act on behalf of the licence holder in the case of their incapacity, including a guardian, committee, Public Guardian and Trustee, tutor, curator, Public Curator, mandatary under a protection mandate or any other person who is appointed to act in a similar capacity; or

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a person has received an authorization in accordance with subsection 23(2) of the Fishery (General) Regulations with respect to the licence.

Section.Text: A licence holder referred to in paragraph 29.1(a) or (c) shall keep a registry of the crew on board the vessel on each fishing trip.

Except in the cases referred to in subsection 29.2(5), a holder of a licence referred to in paragraph 29.1(a) or (c) shall not transfer the use or control of the rights or privileges conferred under that licence.

Except in the cases referred to in subsection 29.2(5), only the holder of a licence referred to in paragraph 29.1(a) or (c) shall use or control the rights and privileges conferred under that licence.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: eel pot means a type of fishing gear used to catch eels without enmeshing them that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contains bait which attracts eels into it through one or more openings, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not have a leader of any kind; (nasse à anguille)

Definition.Text: eel trap means any fishing gear used to catch eels without enmeshing them and includes a fyke net and eel weir but does not include a dip net, eel pot, longline, set line, spear or angling gear; (trappe à anguille)
elver means an eel that is less than 10 cm in length. (civelle)

Section.Text: No person shall fish for eels except by angling or with an eel pot, eel trap, dip net, longline, set line or spear.

Subsection.Text: Every person who fishes for eels, other than elvers, with an eel trap in the inland waters of Nova Scotia shall, during the period beginning at sunrise and ending at sunset,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an eel trap other than a fyke net, provide an opening at least 90 cm wide in the part of the trap that is situated in the deepest water to allow fish to escape; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a fyke net, render the net incapable of catching fish.

Section.Text: No person shall fish for gaspereau except by angling or with a dip net, gill net, square net, trap net or weir.

Subsection.Text: No person shall fish for gaspereau with a gill net that has a mesh size of more than 89 mm.
No person shall fish for gaspereau in the inland and tidal waters of New Brunswick with a gill net that has a mesh size of less than 38 mm.
Subject to subsection (2), no person shall fish for gaspereau in the inland waters of Nova Scotia by any means other than angling during the period beginning at sunset and ending at sunrise.
Subsection (1) does not apply in the inland waters of Halifax and Yarmouth Counties to a person who holds a licence to fish for gaspereau with a dip net at a dip stand.

Section.Text: No person shall, in the inland waters of any river in Nova Scotia,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fish for gaspereau with a square net that is more than 3.65 m2; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: erect or use a square net fixture that extends more than one third of the way across the width of the river or that has an outside wall of more than 9 m in length.

Section.Text: Every holder of a licence to fish for gaspereau with a square net in the inland waters of a river in Nova Scotia shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: during the applicable weekly close time for gaspereau in those waters set out in column IV of Schedule V, remove the square net from the water; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide an opening that is at least 60 cm wide and 60 cm high in the wall of the square net fixture that extends across the river.

Section.Text: No person shall fish for gaspereau in the inland waters of Inverness County with a trap net that is more than 15 m in length, measured from the upstream end of the trap net to the downstream end and including any leader that is attached to it.
No person shall fish for gaspereau in the Gaspereau River, Kings County, Nova Scotia,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with a dip net the opening of which has a circumference of more than 190 cm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: upstream from the mouth of Deep Hollow Brook, except by angling or with a dip net or square net;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: from the White Rock power house to a point 640 m downstream from that power house; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: from a point 183 m downstream from the Trunk 12 highway bridge upstream to the Lanes Mill fish ladder.

Section.Text: No person shall fish for gaspereau in the Tusket River, Nova Scotia, from the Route 423 highway bridge upstream to the power house.

Heading.TitleText: Catch and Release Provisions for Specific Waters

Subsection.Text: No person shall, during any day, continue to angle for salmon in the waters set out in column I of an item of Schedule VII after that person has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: caught and retained from those waters the daily catch and retain quota set out in column III of that item; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 66(2), caught and released in those waters the daily catch and release quota set out in column IV of that item.

Subsection.Text: No person shall, during any year, continue to angle for salmon in the waters set out in column I of an item of Schedule VII after that person has caught and retained from those waters the yearly fishing quota set out in column V of that item.

Heading.TitleText: Catch and Release Provisions by Province

Subsection.Text: No person shall, during any day, continue to angle for salmon in the waters set out in column I of an item of the table to section 63 after that person has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: caught and retained from those waters the daily catch and retain quota set out in column II of that item; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 66(2), caught and released in those waters the daily catch and release quota set out in column III of that item.

Subsection.Text: No person shall, during any year, continue to angle for salmon in the waters set out in column I of an item of the table to section 63 after that person has caught and retained from those waters the yearly fishing quota set out in column IV of that item.
A person may, during the period beginning on April 15 and ending on May 15, fish for or catch and retain salmon from the inland and tidal waters of New Brunswick other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the waters of the Restigouche River upstream from the J.C. Van Horne Bridge in Campbellton; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the waters of the Nepisiguit River upstream from a straight line drawn from grid reference 01487695 to grid reference 01157740 as found on the map Bathurst 21 P/12.

Subsection.Text: Where a person who is fishing for salmon pursuant to subsection (1) has not caught and retained the applicable daily or yearly fishing quota for salmon, the person may catch and release any number of salmon in any day.

Every person who catches and retains a salmon in accordance with these Regulations shall forthwith securely lock or seal on the salmon a salmon tag, as specified in subsection (2), that has been issued to that person and shall do so in accordance with the design of the tag and so that it cannot be removed without tampering with the lock or seal, breaking or cutting the tag or cutting or tearing any part of the salmon.
A salmon tag that is affixed to a salmon shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a blue tag, where the salmon was caught and retained by angling, and shall be a tag specific to a salmon 63 cm or more in length where the salmon is 63 cm or more in length; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a brown tag, where the salmon was caught and retained under a written permission referred to in section 4 of the Act or was taken from an aquaculture area or site or a privately owned fish pond.

Section.Text: No person shall import a salmon into a province unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an import tag issued with a licence to import salmon set out in item 9 of the table to section 5 is affixed to that salmon in the manner described in subsection 67(1) prior to its entry into the province or immediately upon its entry into the province; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it bears a salmon tag.

Section.Text: No person shall have on board any vessel for which a registration card has been issued any salmon to which a blue salmon tag is affixed.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall possess a salmon unless a salmon tag is affixed thereto.

Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who is cooking or smoking a salmon if the tag that was removed from it at the time cooking or smoking commenced is readily available for inspection by a fishery officer or fishery guardian.

Subject to subsection (2), where a salmon is caught by angling and retained, the person who hooked the salmon, whether or not that person landed the salmon, shall be regarded as having caught and retained it, and shall tag it in accordance with section 67.

Where a fishing guide who is authorized to provide guide services under an Act of the legislature of a province hooks a salmon on behalf of a person who has a licence to fish for salmon and who has paid the fishing guide for guide services, subsection (1) does not apply to the fishing guide and the person shall, for the purposes of that subsection, be considered to have hooked the salmon.

Section.Text: Sections 67, 70 and 71 do not apply in respect of salmon caught under the authority of a licence issued under the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations.

Section.Text: No person shall fish for smelt except by angling or with a bag net, box net, dip net, gill net or spear.

Paragraph.Label: (a)

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: catch and retain any landlocked salmon that is less than 50 cm in length or more than 63 cm in length;

Paragraph.Label: (d)

Paragraph.Label: (e)

Heading.Label: PART XIX
Heading.TitleText: Boundary Waters Between New Brunswick and the State of Maine

Section.Text: This Part applies in respect of recreational fishing for smelt, whitefish and sport fish, other than salmon, in the following inland waters of New Brunswick that border on waters in the State of Maine:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the St. Francis River and Glasier Lake in Madawaska County and that portion of the Saint John River in Madawaska County;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Monument Brook, North Lake, the Thoroughfare between North Lake and (East) Grand Lake, (East) Grand Lake, Mud Lake, the St. Croix River, Spednic Lake and Palfrey Lake in York County; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the St. Croix River, Grand Falls Flowage and Woodland Flowage in Charlotte County.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fish for sport fish or whitefish except by angling; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fish for smelt except by angling or with a dip net.

Subsection.Text: A person who fishes in accordance with subsection 119(2) may fish with set lines.
No person shall fish with more than five set lines.
Every person who fishes with set lines shall attend those lines and maintain an unobstructed view of those lines.
Subject to subsection (2), no person shall fish during the period beginning on October 1 and ending on April 14.

A person may, during the period beginning on January 1 and ending on March 31, fish through a man-made hole in the ice in Glasier Lake, North Lake, the Thoroughfare between North Lake and (East) Grand Lake, (East) Grand Lake, Mud Lake, Spednic Lake, Palfrey Lake, Grand Falls Flowage or Woodland Flowage.
No person shall, during the period beginning on January 1 and ending on March 31, fish during the period beginning one-half hour after sunset and ending one-half hour before sunrise.

No person shall, during the period beginning on April 1 and ending on December 31, catch and retain in any day more fish of a species set out in column I of an item of the table to this section than the daily fishing quota set out in column II of that item.
No person shall, during the period beginning on April 1 and ending on December 31, catch and retain in any day more sport fish in the aggregate than the lesser of five fish and 3.5 kg plus one fish.

No person shall, during the period beginning on January 1 and ending on March 31, catch and retain in any day more fish of a species set out in column I of an item of the table to this section than the daily fishing quota set out in column III of that item.
No person shall, during the period beginning on January 1 and ending on March 31, catch and retain in any day more sport fish in the aggregate than the lesser of three fish and 3.5 kg plus one fish.
